title: Watershed Lab
text:
Welcome
The Watershed Lab is an interdisciplinary research group studying watershed processes, with focus on biogeochemistry and hydrology. We want to understand how watershed processes operate, and how they may respond to and shape environmental changes.
What is a watershed? It is the geospatial scale that is defined by the natural flow of water on land. This scale provides a unit for understanding flows of matter and physical processes on land. It‚Äôs greatest strenght is its interconnecteness - one effect upstream can be perceived over kilometers downstreams.
Our research is based mostly on field observations and combines multiple tools including automated and continuous in-situ sensor measurements, isotopic tracers, ground or drone-based imagery including, RGB, thermal infrared images and LIDAR.
We are based at the departement of geography of University of Montr√©al, located at Campus-MIL

title: Watershed Lab
text:
How to use this website
This websites serves as a diffusion platform for the research we do collectively in the lab. Here, you will find:

Tutorials and data viz material in the resources page.
Individual portfolios from team members with details on their research projects.
A list of publications, field sites, tools and infrastructures that form the core of our work.

We hold strong beliefs in the importance of making our science and knowledge accessible.
All material featured here is licensed under the CC-XYZ common. Please use and share accordingly.

title: Permanent Solution: Remove [Journal Article] with Lua Filter
text:
EndNote exports include type = {Journal Article} which displays as [Journal Article] in your citations.



Use a Lua filter to automatically remove this text during rendering - no need to clean your .bib file!





Create a file called remove-type-brackets.lua in your publications/ folder:
-- remove-type-brackets.lua
-- Removes [Journal Article], [Book], etc. from bibliography output

function Str(el)
  -- Remove [Journal Article] and similar patterns
  local text = el.text
  text = text:gsub("%[Journal Article%]", "")
  text = text:gsub("%[Book%]", "")
  text = text:gsub("%[Conference Paper%]", "")
  text = text:gsub("%[Book Chapter%]", "")
  text = text:gsub("%[Thesis%]", "")
  
  return pandoc.Str(text)
end



Add the filter to your YAML header:
---
title: "Publications"
bibliography: campeau_pubs.bib
csl: global-change-biology.csl
nocite: '@*'
filters:
  - remove-type-brackets.lua
---



quarto preview
The [Journal Article] text should now be gone!




Your publications folder should look like this:
publications/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.qmd
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ campeau_pubs.bib              ‚Üê Original file, no cleaning needed!
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ global-change-biology.csl
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ remove-type-brackets.lua      ‚Üê New filter file



The Lua filter: 1. Runs during Quarto rendering 2. Scans all text in the bibliography 3. Removes any [Journal Article], [Book], etc. text 4. Outputs clean citations



Now when you update publications:

Add new paper to EndNote
Export entire library to .bib format
Replace campeau_pubs.bib (don‚Äôt clean it!)
Run quarto render

Done! The filter automatically removes [Journal Article] every time.



‚úÖ No manual cleaning - Use EndNote exports directly
‚úÖ Automatic - Works for all future publications
‚úÖ Comprehensive - Removes all type indicators (Journal Article, Book, etc.)
‚úÖ Maintenance-free - Set it once, forget about it



If [Journal Article] still appears:

Check that remove-type-brackets.lua is in the publications/ folder
Verify the filters: line is in your YAML header
Make sure the file name matches exactly (case-sensitive)
Try running quarto render --verbose to see if filter is loading

If you get a filter error:
Check that the Lua file has no syntax errors. The file should be exactly as shown above.
Alternative: Use JavaScript Instead
If Lua filters don‚Äôt work, you can add this to the bottom of your index.qmd:
<script>
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
  // Remove [Journal Article] and similar text
  const refs = document.querySelectorAll('#refs .csl-entry, #refs div');
  refs.forEach(function(ref) {
    ref.innerHTML = ref.innerHTML
      .replace(/\[Journal Article\]/g, '')
      .replace(/\[Book\]/g, '')
      .replace(/\[Conference Paper\]/g, '')
      .replace(/\[Book Chapter\]/g, '');
  });
});
</script>
This JavaScript solution runs in the browser and strips out the unwanted text.



Use the Lua filter (cleaner, runs during build)
OR
Use the JavaScript (if Lua filter has issues)
Both work equally well - pick whichever is easier for you to set up!

Tutorials


[1] 2

title: Team Members
text:
Co-supervised with Jean-Fran√ßois Lapierre
What is the impact of wildfires on aquatic carbon cycling? For my thesis, I use a combination of approaches to answer this vast question at different spatial and temporal scales.
My field site within the Watershed Lab is located in the north of Saguenay. There I monitor water level across two hydrological gradients, from headwater stream, headwater lake, to merging lakes downstream in catchments that were affected by wildfires and ones that weren‚Äôt. In the burned catchments, I also monitor dissolved gas concentrations CO‚ÇÇ, CH‚ÇÑ and O‚ÇÇ and I apply carbon and water isotope tracers along these two transects.
[Find out more ‚Üí]

text:
Co-supervised with Jean-Fran√ßois Lapierre

title: Team Members
text:
Master researchers


L√©onie Thibault-Rousseau
How do storm events shape lateral carbon export in forested headwater streams?
I lead the SBL headwater catchment where I have instrumented a headwater stream and a preferential groundwater flow slope with sensors. I measure continuously CO‚ÇÇ, CH‚ÇÑ and O‚ÇÇ gas concentration, along side C-DOM, conductivity, water table height and temperature.
[Find out more ‚Üí]










Jo√´l Gaxotte
Co-supervised with Alexis Berg
What can Earth System Models tell us about the future of land carbon export to oceans globally?
I use the CNRM-ESM2-1 model to test the effect of different climate change scenarios on organic carbon export from rivers to oceans worldwide
I produced the tutorial ‚ÄúHow to delineate a watershed on R‚Äù, which you can find in the resources page.










Vincent Villeneuve
Co-supervised with Jean-Fran√ßois Lapierre
How much carbon is exported and emitted from agricultural streams across southern Qu√©bec and what are the landscape properties that shape these spatial patterns?
[Find out more ‚Üí]

title: Team Members
text:
Bachelor researchers


L√©on Leblanc
How much do headwater stream surfaces expand and contract over time and what are the potential implications for annual stream CO‚ÇÇ emissions.
I use trail cameras and pressure transducers to track the activation of intermittent streams. I coupled this with drone surveys using thermal infrared imagery. My field site is located at the SBL.
[Find out more ‚Üí]

title: Audrey Campeau
text:
Hi üëã I‚Äôm Audrey,
I am an assistant professor in physical geography at the department of geography at the Universit√© de Montr√©al üá®üá¶. I specialize in watershed biogeochemistry and hydrology. My research focuses on headwater catchments, those that have the strongest land-water connectivityüíß.
I am fascinated with data visualization and I love the endless possibilities that programming can offer. I am a strong advocate for open and FARE science.
My personal time is devoted to my three young children üö∏. When I can find time for myself, I like to spend it on creation üé® and the outdoors ü•æ. I love all textile arts! If you see me wearing something woolly, I probably made it üß∂

title: Audrey Campeau
text:
Teaching
I teach several courses at the department including the first field course (Terrain 1 | GEO1315), the watershed course (Bassins Versants | GEO3162) and the ecosystem dynamics course (Dynamiques des √âcosyst√®mes | GEO6100).





You can visualise the data collected for the physical geography portion of the field courses üëá across different editions. Those reports were produced in collaboration with students and grad-students as part of individual projects using R programming and Quarto.
